Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research RUI: Decadal cyclicity in NAO proxies from northwest Iceland lake sediments
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical Description
This four-year, field- and lab-intensive work extends the paleo-North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO) record to 2000 years BP, building on existing paleolimnological datasets of pollen, organic and inorganic chemistry, mineral magnetism and particle-size that show strong qualitative linkages with NAO activity on Iceland. It develops new quantitative linkages with the NAO from these same proxies in northwest Iceland lake, soil and stream deposits of the last 2000 years, using calibration datasets of watershed soil and lake sediments derived from current depositional environments. It identifies the specific environmental mechanisms responsible for creating distinct, 80-100 year cycles in the mineral deposits of Icelandic lakes and tests these hypotheses:
1. periods of intensified storminess and precipitation on Iceland, such as occur when the NAO index is high and positive, consistently and predictably mobilize minerals from watershed soil reserves and alter lake water characteristics to form distinctive lake sediment deposits, and
2. watershed disturbances related to human occupation and land-use increase the amplitude and/or recurrence interval of the decadal cycle, and
3. conservation protection of the lakes' watersheds in the last 30 years has resulted in a trend towards that of a pre-occupation state, as documented in the lake sediment geochemistry.

Broader impact
The North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO) is part of a global-scale circulation pattern that dominates Northern Hemisphere atmospheric conditions. It is linked to patterns of drought, flooding and severe weather in North America, Europe and the Middle-East. Prior work has shown that the NAO undergoes regular cycles that disturb watershed soils and alter nutrient inflows to lakes and rivers, at least on Iceland. This works uses that lake effect to "see" into the past 2000 years and identify when the NAO was most active. Because human occupation of Iceland began just over 1000 years ago, and this project produces records of change covering the last 2000 years, it offers a unique look at the human role in magnifying the impacts of NAO-related climate changes on fragile landscapes, such as occur in Iceland and in many other previously glaciated regions. By assessing the response of watersheds to repeated climate disturbances, like the NAO, before and after human land use and before and after conservation management, this work provides insight on the usefulness of conservation efforts in mitigating human aspects of climate change. This project also provides much needed research, education, field and laboratory training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students at institutions with relatively limited research opportunities (Plymouth State University and Salem State College), providing access and engagement with three tier-one, research institutions (U. Maine, U. Colorado and U. Minnesota). Students are involved at every level of the project and learn state-of-the-art interdisciplinary approaches typically practiced at research-oriented institutions. It creates opportunities for students to communicate complex ideas associated with research findings in oral and written publications. The five senior researchers involved in this project also receive training in state-of-the-art cross-disciplinary approaches and applications, which enhances their teaching and research capabilities. This work involves significant use of National Laboratory facilities at LacCore and Large Lakes Observatory and combines efforts of 3 New England campuses, leveraging existing facilities and human resources and building new regional capacity.

Project goals:

Natural deposits in some Icelandic lake sediments show the presence of a persistent, multi-decadal cycle, extending over hundreds of years. While similar cycles have recently been identified in records from ice cores, corals and cave deposits, it's been difficult to pin down the mechanism, or mechanisms, behind the cyclical behavior. This study examines the validity of some "most-likely" explanations, using a 80-110 year cycle discovered in sediments of four lakes in Iceland's Westfjord region. It tests several ideas about the source of minerals that form the chemical peaks in each cycle:

1)   that river floods, during years of particularly high flows, carry the chemicals as part of their sediment load;

2)   that intensified erosion of the watershed soils around each lake provide the source materials; and

3)   that human land-use and soil disturbances contribute to the cyclical pattern.

 

The first two hypotheses require an increase in rain or snow amounts, or a change in intensity of freeze-thaw patterns in the soils, to cause increases in sediment transport. A regional weather phenomenon called the North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO) is known to create seasonal changes in sea level pressure and temperature in the Atlantic. This project examined the idea that different phases of the NAO affect precipitation amounts in Iceland's sub-regions. It tested the third hypotheses, about human land-use affects, by comparing the lake records from the interval before versus after Vikings arrived on Iceland in AD 875.

 

Findings and outcomes: Intellectual merit

While rivers in the region carry a complex suite of dissolved chemicals, turbidity levels are very low even during periods of rapid snowmelt. So, changes in river sediment load are unlikely to account for the chemical cycles in the lake sediments. But some of the rivers' dissolved loads do include elements, such as vanadium, that vary within the 80-110 year lake sediment cycle. Vanadium, among other elements, accumulates in the soils (by chemical weathering) over the winter months, and is released when the soils thaw. Since soil temperatures affect the duration and intensity of chemical weathering, the cycles may originate from variations in depth or intensity of permafrost.

 

The lakes' sediments are largely comprised of contributions from watershed soils, as opposed to just algal growth. Although the soils contain chemical compositions similar to that in the lake deposits, some of the chemicals only occur in large amounts in the deepest soil layers. This suggests that the lake sediment cycles may be associated with erosion of the entire soil packet, not just the surface material. Deep erosion today occurs with landslides, gullying and channelization of runoff by sheep trails, all triggered by higher than average amounts of rain or snowmelt, and by thawing of frozen ground. The arrival of human settlers to Iceland's northwest region changed the size of mineral grains transported to the lakes, but it didn't alter the chemical composition of the deposits. The same kinds of chemical variations occur throughout the sediment record, extending over several thousands of years.

 

These findings all point to a land-based mechanism for the cycles. It probably involves a suite of conditions that act to destabilize soils across large regions of the watershed. The existence of the same chemical cycle in several lakes from different locales, occurring over thousands of years, indicates that climate variations are the ultimate cause.
